text: Sokolov avoids using the most common Soviet appellative "tovarishch," opting for a rather general, but still evocative word (cf. Nikolai Nekrasov's "Poet i grazhdanin," "Poet and Citizen," 1856).

An unusual surname, which does not permit standard declination. It literally means "elderly." Ostanin suggests a connection to Boris Pasternak's novel *Doctor Zhivago* by means of the root "zhiv" (to live) (10). Read the original [here](http://www.vehi.net/pasternak/). Likewise, he notes, too, that Alexander Pushkin considered including a story entitled "Notes of an Elderly Person" in his cycle of short stories, *The Tales of Belkin*. Read the original [here](https://ilibrary.ru/text/89/index.html) and an English translation [here](https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/55219/pg55219-images.html).

text: The dead rise out of the river (of death, of oblivion). Writing about Sokolov's essay "On Secret Tablets," D. Barton Johnson describes how "Sokolov recounts a strange conversation a with drunken, illiterate old hunter on the Volga, the prototype for Krylobyl [...] The old man counsels Sasha — 'Don't go to America, San'ka.' The idea had never been mentioned, nor had Sokolov even remotely considered it. The novel, finished in America, details, in passing, the bizarre deaths of most of its characters. Shortly before its publication, Sokolov received a letter from the Volga village where he had lived. Many of the novel's prototypes had died their fictional deaths. They had predicted his fate (America); he had predicted theirs" ("Sasha Sokolov's Major Essays" 234). Read the essay [here](https://philologist.livejournal.com/10961052.html).
Low: one near and dear. High/dated: eternal, constant.

text: According to Boguslawski's annotations, *zimar'* refers to Andrei Voznesensky's poem "Song-travesty from the spectacle 'Antiworlds'" (1963) ("Annotations" 233). It combines the word *zima* (winter) with the ending of *ianvar'* (January) to refer to the winter time. Perhaps a reference to the Orion constellation visible during the winter solstice. According to the mythology, Orion fell in love with Merope (along with many other women) and raped her, similar to the story told here by Orina. Constellation-heavens motif.

text: Ilya. Details like the crutches, called "inventar'" further below, suggest this is Ilya, yet he is here said to be a child born out of wedlock, just like Yakov. Once again, the characters of the supposed father (Ilya) and supposed son (Yakov) are intertwined. Alexander Boguslawski likewise suggests that this is Ilya and his crutches ("How Sokolov's" 212).

text: Icon corn (sacred corner, red corner) — a corner in Eastern Orthodox homes devoted to worship featuring an icon. From the Greek εικονοστάσι (red, bright-shining, or beautiful corner). Depicted here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/b5/Wassilij_Maximowitsch_Maximow_002b.jpg)

Всех скорбящих Радость. The Joy of All Who Sorrow — Mary, the Mother of Jesus. Here the reference is to an icon of Mary. All the characters in the novel do, indeed, feel lasting sorrow. Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/2/2f/Radost_ordynka.jpg)

text: Ilya, much like the reader, begins to wrestle with the narrative chronology of the novel. If the reason that Ilya took revenge by killing the dogs was that his crutches were stolen, then how did he beat the dog on the ice with them and how does he have them now? text: The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the "town of beggars."

text: Same as шакал (jackal). Pictured here: ![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/82/Canis_aureus_-_golden_jackal.jpg) Ilya mistakes the animal (actually a dog) for a wolf. As Ostanin notes, in Egyptian mythology, Anubis, the god of the dead who would ferry the deceased to the underworld, takes the form of a jackal or a man with the head of a jackal. Animal motif.

text: Krylobyl participated in Ilya's drowning after the latter killed Yakov's dogs. A reference to the Last Judgment — according to Christian faith, the time when Jesus will return and judge all souls to determine whether they will reside in Heaven or Hell. See [Matthew 25:31-46](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew%2025%3A31-46&version=ESV,NRT). Johnson writes of Sokolov's time as a game warden on the Upper Volga: "Sokolov's predecessor, whose cabin and effects he had inherited, had come to a bad end. There had been an incident involving the hunting dogs of a neighbor. A feud ensued, and the game garden had been found drowned. The official investigation had yielded little but suspicions" ("Sasha Sokolov: A Literary Biography" 208).
Literary: to say, speak, pronounce.
Dated: shovels.

The Last Judgment — according to Christian faith, the time when Jesus will return and judge all souls to determine whether they will reside in Heaven or Hell. This reference continues the line of thought started by Ilya a few lines above when he refers to Krylobyl's acts being judged and forgiven. See [Matthew 25:31-46](https://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Matthew%2025%3A31-46&version=ESV,NRT).

text: Ilya invites a dead dog to talk with him, so, of course, his words (language) will be incomprehensible. Ilya (and Sokolov behind him) may as well be addressing the reader, too. The words of the novel may yet remain cryptic even by this point. Animal-human motif.
